name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: Comparing the power of different measures of ERP to predict stock market returns over next decade, the current implied ERP does best (albeit with noise) and that historical ERPs do worst.  (Look at correlations with actual 10-yr ERPs)   https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/8z32vRGF7v

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: The price of risk (ERP) in equity markets moves mostly in sync with the price of risk in bond markets (default spreads) and when it does not (late 1990s, 2002-08), chaos ensues. Real estate is behaving more like stocks now than a divergent asset class.  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/CRZigCSPSk

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: An implied ERP, computed from current stock prices and expected future cash flows, is a more forward-looking and dynamic estimate. At the start of 2021, this ERP was 4.72% after a tumultuous ride during 2020.  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/J8qGOMVITd

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: In practice, most analysts and companies estimate equity risk premiums by looking at the past (historical data), but that is not only backward looking, but it yields static and noisy estimates of the ERP, even for a market like the US, with a long history.  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/dIzTakOrdg

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: As the ERP rises and falls, it drives what investors are willing to pay for stocks, and what companies demand as hurdle rates. Views on whether it is too high or too low determine whether stocks are collectively under or over valued.  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/yiMZhZ0XBj

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: The equity risk premium (ERP) is the price of risk in equity markets, the receptacle for all our fears. Each year, since 2008, I have updated a paper that includes everything I know about ERP. (Warning: It is 130 pages long...) Here is the 2021 version:  https://t.co/yALxcDRxex  https://t.co/m0SxJizOiH

tweet: @gecornelius They do. That is why it is 25-27% for the US, rather than the 21% federal rate.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: Bottom line. Focus less on raising corporate tax rates, and more on removing the bloat in the tax code. In short, corporate taxes are for generating revenues, not an instrument for punishing bad & rewarding good companies.  https://t.co/3ON1zHEhBc

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: And the differences across US industries in tax burden are a testimonial to how these credits and deductions create inequitable burdens across industries.  https://t.co/3ON1zHEhBc  https://t.co/cle3LYaHyF

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: But the 2017 tax reform act rates is not to blame, for lower taxes. While effective tax rates dropped in its aftermath, taxable income increased, as did cash taxes paid.  https://t.co/3ON1zHEhBc  https://t.co/vBzAszri7f

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: But US companies pay less in effective tax rates than companies elsewhere in the world, largely because of the bloat in the US tax code.  https://t.co/3ON1zHEhBc  https://t.co/fnpeNnEPdd

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: As another corporate tax code rewrite looms,  both sides of the debate will present opinions as facts. I look at how much US companies pay in taxes, relative to non-US companies. At 25-27%, US statutory tax rates are in the middle of the pack:  https://t.co/3ON1zHEhBc  https://t.co/t7XlFsFV1F

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @profgalloway @waltmossberg As for the question of whether market value is a good measure of contribution to society, it is not, and it is not meant to be. That‚Äôs a debate for another time & place. Scott‚Äôs point is about the market‚Äôs assessment of Uber‚Äôs value.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @profgalloway @waltmossberg Enterprise value is a more complete measure of market value, but for Uber, with its mninimal debt, the difference from market cap is small. For the airlines, with their debt load, the enterprise value is much larger than market cap.

name: Aswath Damodaran

tweet: Interest rates can rise because investors expect a pick up in real growth or because they fear rising inflation; the former is benign & the latter malignant. The question that remains to be answered is which effect will dominate in 2021.  https://t.co/d3mWSLaDIT  https://t.co/OSdRYeBrOj

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @jamiehannaford When capitalizing R&D, you don‚Äôt forecast R&D. You just use R&D expenses from the most recent 12 months and prior years.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist @APompliano It is a collectible like Picassos and baseball cards, perfectly acceptable for an individual, who want to bet on their future movements, but not for a car or software company.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @anthonissen @VicLundquist That‚Äôs the pitch. Millennial gold, but only time will tell.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist @LeoSmigel I think you may be missing my point, but I tried. Try this:  https://t.co/6fDfm7TQ3B.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @LeoSmigel @VicLundquist You price by looking at what people are paying for similar investments (house, baseball card, Picasso). You value based on the capacity of an asset to generate cash flows. Stocks can be either valued or priced. Currencies and collectibles can only be priced.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist No company should muddy up its operating story by holding bitcoin, instead of cash, and becoming a crypto play on the side. And I would say that even if you were a bitcoin bull. And it is not dozens of public companies, just two (non-financial).. Microstrategy & Tesla..

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist Nope. It has a price, and that price comes from its scarcity and its staying power. It has no intrinsic value. Put simply, if we decided that Willie Mays was not special, you know what would happen.... that same thing that happened to the Mark McGuire and Sammy Sosa cards.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist Since you seem to be the one buying it, you tell me. If it is a currency, it a really inefficient one. It could be a collectible, but is it millennial gold or a very expensive version of beanie babies? And no, you cannot designate something an asset, just because you buy it.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @VicLundquist Currencies are priced, relative to each other. The prices are exchange rates and reflect differential inflation, with lower inflation currencies gaining at the expense of higher inflation currencies in the long term. And nope, neither currencies nor collectibles can be valued.

name: Aswath Damodaran

name: Aswath Damodaran

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: As markets made their way back in 2020, I use company-level data to chronicle the winners and losers from the crisis, by looking at market cap and operating shifts during the year, and find that the flexible & the young won out over the rigid & the old.  https://t.co/wdZvFiIoIr  https://t.co/LzQvxSaJsq

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: If you are looking for an objective, theoretical perspective, this paper will disappoint you. It is data-driven, agnostic about theory, and personal, as I draw on my real-time posts to chronicle my ups and downs during 2020:  https://t.co/wdZvFiIoIr  https://t.co/GuWTLz12wR

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread You are right. If you have a traded bond, you can back out the probability of failure from the price. I have a spreadsheet that does that on my website.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread The bond yield is based upon the presumption that the promised bond payments will be made (just check the YTM calculations). It is therefore a cost of capital for a going concern that makes it debt payments.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom I like Shiller, but I think the Shiller PE was a bludgeon for market assesssment, and not amount of tinkering with it can fix its fundamental flaws.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread First, when was the last time any one valued a company with probability-weighted cash flows? Second, even if you did, the discount rate is designed to reflect the likelihood that you will be wrong on your year 3 cash flows, not that there will be no year 3.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread To get the failure probability, you can use the failure probabilities in bond ratings, the likelihood of failure in a simulation or base it on historical failure rates for firms in that grouping.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @MarkRozeboom @NotQuiteMidlife @Wildcat_Finance @excess_spread Discount rates are blunt instruments that capture continuous risk in operations. Failure risk is discrete & often catastrophic. You cannot bring that into a DCF. It has to be a post DCF adjustment, consequential for young & distressed companies, and for all firms, during crises.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @thomasb1231 @Mattmilladb8 If that were the case, anyone who can prove their identity should be given a blue check, right? So, why is it reserved for only some people and not others?

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @AJSalkan @ScottWapnerCNBC Actually, even the Fed is a bystander. It is driven by fundamentals, as are earnings and cash flows. My point today is that investors seem to be making contradictory assumptions on the two fronts, building in expectations of strong growth in the latter but not in the former.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @AJSalkan @ScottWapnerCNBC Because rates are a symptom, not a cause. Rates can go up for good reasons (higher growth) or bad ones (higher inflation), and the same for rates going down. That is why focusing on rates alone can lead you down blind alleys.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @shyamvasudevan_ @rhymesjoel If you think it is easier to deflate than inflate, and that inflation does not have real causes & consequences, I hope that for your sake, you never live in a high inflation environment. Nobody who has is this blas√© about it.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @shyamvasudevan_ @rhymesjoel Inflation and growth are ultimately real phenomena. The Fed can influence expectations, but not if it it is at war with reality. Trying to signal low inflation, when inflation is high, will not work. Take a look at every past inflationary episode & central banks become helpless.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @shyamvasudevan_ @rhymesjoel That is a very selective reading off expectations. The bond market sets rates based upon expectations of inflation & growth first, and looks at Fed policy as signaling future values of these. And the Fed sets only one rate, the Fed Funds rate, which is not a money market rate.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @orlando_mac This is the problem when you use compass directions to talk about the economy. Is north lower or higher? I think that you mean lower, but if 730,000 weekly claims and a 6.8% unemployment rate is your definition of going north, I would hate to see what going south is.

name: Aswath Damodaran

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @aniketchatt @Anto400 @jnptl @APompliano Demand and supply set the price. Y=X. You can try to guess where the price is going next, which is trading, not investing, but there is nothing wrong with that.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @Anto400 @aniketchatt @jnptl @APompliano Demand and supply gives you price. Cash flows give you value. We need to stop using the words interchangeably.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @trengriffin I agree. I argue that for ‚Äúvalue-based‚Äù investing to make a return, investors have to expand their skills to value users, subscriber and platforms, and their tools to better deal with uncertainty. You already do, but most self-proclaimed believers in value don‚Äôt.

name: Aswath Damodaran
tweet: @trengriffin I don‚Äôt do that in the paper. I draw a contrast, but I also point to an unpalatable truth. Value investing in all of its forms, from the lazy (just buy low PE &PBV) to the Buffett/Munger version, has had a tough decade. It may be a passing phase, but it is still worth asking why.
